awd_titl_txt: Gravitational Effects on Rotating Stars and Deep Water Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to investigate several important mathematical questions arising in the study of fluid flows that are significantly influenced by gravity. Two major sources of these questions are models of rotating stars and galaxies, and models of deep water waves in the ocean. The study of equilibrium shape and density distribution of rotating stars is a classical question in the history of mathematical physics. Early efforts beginning in the eighteenth century were devoted to finding ellipsoidal shapes with constant density. In the twentieth century, major progress was made by solving equations describing compressible fluids, thus allowing a more realistic model of stars with variable gaseous density. The mathematical method used to construct such solutions involves putting the same amount of gas in different shapes and density distributions, and finding one with the least physical energy. However, such a method only provides proof for existence of solutions, without delivering too much information on the shape of the star, or how the solution varies as the rotation speed of the star varies. In this project, the investigator aims to provide new existence proofs using a different method, which involves continuously deforming the shape of a round, non-rotating star to arrive at a rotating star solution. The new method is intended to return information about shape and dependence on rotation speed. For deep water waves, the investigator will study certain important model equations that describe internal waves below the ocean surface as well as spectacular phenomena in the atmosphere, such as the "Morning Glory" cloud seen in northeastern Australia. The internal waves described by such models have practical significance; for example, internal waves can interact with surface ocean waves to produce rogue waves that can damage or destroy ocean vessels or fixed structures.

More specifically, the project aims to prove existence of rotating star solutions to the Euler-Poisson and Vlasov-Poisson equations, using an implicit function theorem type perturbation technique. Apart from proving detailed analytical estimates involving spaces adapted to the problem, the investigator will need to study the linearized operator by proving a vanishing theorem about a certain integro-differential equation for functions in the kernel. The research will study continuation of the solution curve to faster rotation speed using topological degree arguments, and discover possible breakdown mechanisms of the solution curve. In addition, the investigator plans to examine the phenomenon of mass bound on rotating white dwarf solutions to the Euler-Poisson equations, using both variational methods and spectral analysis. For models involving deep water waves, the project will explore the completely integrable aspect of the Benjamin-Ono equation. Building on previous work, the investigator will study existence, uniqueness, and asymptotic properties of the Jost solutions proposed in the Fokas-Ablowitz inverse scattering transform. These questions are closely related to the continuous spectrum of certain singular integral perturbations of the derivative operator.

por.por_cntn:
The internal structure of stars is a problem of long and rich history in physics. Ever since Newton discovered his law of universal gravitation, models have been made, and calculations performed to explore the motion and density distribution of gas underneath the stellar surface. The mathematical difficulty of the problem is further increased if one attempts to study stars with complicated differential rotation, whose angular velocity profile allows different layers of the star to rotate at different speeds. In this project, new methods were discovered to solve a few widely studied fundamental models of rotating stars and galaxies. In the past, most solutions to these models were produced by the energy minimization method. This is a scheme to search among all possible configurations of gas densities to find one with the least thermal, rotational and gravitational energy. While being able to produce solutions in theory, this energy-based method has many deficiencies. First of all, it is computationally expensive to perform. It also relies on a special energy structure in the equations involved, and breaks down if one tries to generalize the model to include realistic physical effects, such as stellar magnetic fields, entropy variation, or to include models of dilute gas and galaxies. In addition, the energy-based method does not provide insight into the structure of the continuum family of stars with varying speed of rotation. A deeper investigation of such structure may lead to better understanding of stellar evolution and stellar collapse. In this project, the principle investigator (PI) developed a continuity method that produces solutions by continuously deforming a non-rotating star to rotating ones with larger and larger angular speed. As a culmination of this new method, he proved a result showing that as the rotation speed continues to increase, either the size of the star must expand to infinity, indicating a stellar blow up, or the gas density somewhere in the star must grow to infinity, indicating a stellar collapse. This new method turns out to be more robust than the old one, and has been adapted to many generalized models.

 

On a different front, the project developed the theory of internal deep water waves. The problem involves a model of layered fluids, and the waves are supported on the interface of different fluid layers. Such a model is relevant in oceanography, where sea water is layered by different salinity, and in atmospheric science, when special conditions cause air of different temperature and density to form layers. The model helps understand rogue waves in the ocean and spectacular phenomena of cloud structure, such as the morning glory cloud in the sky. A mathematical solution scheme was proposed in the 1980’s, but no rigorous proofs have been found regarding how the scheme will work for general data. This project greatly advanced our current understanding of this solution scheme by proving existence of solutions for a large class of general initial data. This will serve to open up a new route to proving formulas of long-time behavior of these deep internal waves.

 

This project was originally started when the PI was at Brown University, and was continued and completed after he relocated to the University of Oklahoma. During the course of the project, many graduate and undergraduate students were introduced to the related problems and methods through multiple reading courses (with an undergraduate student at Brown and a graduate student at OU), numerous student seminar talks and countless private discussions. Part of the goal of the project was to attract and prepare students to engage in research on mathematical physics and differential equations, and more broadly, to recruit future researchers in STEM fields in general. It is the PI’s conviction that both the student bodies at the two institutions and the research field itself will benefit in the long run by exposing more students to real research problems, especially by creating an inclusive and nourishing environment for underrepresented minority students.
